message_1: What is the enthalpy change for the reaction of burning 1 mole of methane gas (CH4) at standard conditions (25°C and 1 atm)?
message_2:
To calculate the enthalpy change for the combustion of 1 mole of methane gas (CH4) at standard conditions, we need to use the standard enthalpies of formation for the reactants and products involved in the reaction.

The balanced chemical equation for the combustion of methane is:

CH₄(g) + 2O₂(g) → CO₂(g) + 2H₂O(l)

The standard enthalpies of formation (ΔHf°) for the substances involved in the reaction are:

ΔHf°(CH₄) = -74.8 kJ/mol
ΔHf°(O₂) = 0 kJ/mol (since it is an element in its standard state)
ΔHf°(CO₂) = -393.5 kJ/mol
ΔHf°(H₂O) = -285.8 kJ/mol

Using Hess's Law, the enthalpy change for the reaction (ΔHrxn) can be calculated as follows:

ΔHrxn = [ΔHf°(products) - ΔHf°(reactants)]

ΔHrxn = [1 × (-393.5 kJ/mol) + 2 × (-285.8 kJ/mol)] - [1 × (-74.8 kJ/mol) + 2 × 0 kJ/mol]

ΔHrxn = (-393.5 - 571.6 + 74.8) kJ/mol

ΔHrxn = -890.3 kJ/mol

So, the enthalpy change for the combustion of 1 mole of methane gas at standard conditions is -890.3 kJ/mol.
